Area of plane figures

1. Area of quadrilaterals

Perimeter and area involving pythagoras

Study the figure XYWVU below. The figure is drawn to scale.

Side XY⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯=6kmXY¯=6km , YW⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯=YW¯= Not given, WV⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯=4kmWV¯=4km, VU⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯=xVU¯=x, UX⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯=13kmUX¯=13km.

Calculate the perimeter and the area of the figure. Round your answer to one decimal place.

Answer:
  1. Perimeter = kmkm
  2. Area = km2km2
numeric
numeric
STEP: <no title>
[−4 points ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

You first need to calculate the value of xx.

xx = 7,27,2 kmkm

The perimeter = 43,243,2 kmkm

The area =9090km2km2

  • We need to notice 3 things from the given information:

    1. YW⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯=XU⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯YW¯=XU¯ (Opposite sides of a rectangle are equal)
    2. XY⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯=WU⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯XY¯=WU¯ (Opposite sides of a rectangle are equal
    3. x is the hypotenuse side of right ΔΔ WVU. Using the Theorem of Pythagoras:
      VU⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯2VU⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯2VU⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯VU⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯=WV⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯2+UW⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯2=(4)2+(6)2=52‾‾‾√=7,2kmVU¯2=WV¯2+UW¯2VU¯2=(4)2+(6)2VU¯=52VU¯=7,2km

  • Perimeter is the border or outer boundary of a two-dimensional figure.

    PerimeterPerimeter=Sum of the distance around=6+13+4+7,2+13=6+13+4+7,2+13=43,2kmPerimeter=Sum of the distance around=6+13+4+7,2+13=6+13+4+7,2+13Perimeter=43,2km
  • Area is the amount of space inside the boundary of a two-dimensional shape.
AreaAAreaBAreaTotal=length×width=6×13=78km2=12base×height=12(6×4)=12km2=AreaA+AreaB=90km2AreaA=length×width=6×13=78km2AreaB=12base×height=12(6×4)=12km2AreaTotal=AreaA+AreaB=90km2

Area formulae for the basic shapes

For each of the shapes shown below, identify the correct formula for the area of the shape.

Shape A Shape B
Choice Area Formula
1 A=h2(a+b)A=h2(a+b)
2 A=bhA=bh
3 A=πr2A=πr2
4 A=bh2A=bh2
5 None of the above
Answer:

Shape A:

Shape B:

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]
Look in your textbook or follow this link to get to a summary of the Area Formulae.
STEP: <no title>
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

Area is the surface of a shape or object that you can cover or paint. The pictures below show the shapes in the question "painted" in a colour; the painted place is the area of the shape.

You need to memorise each of the area formulae!!

  • Trapezium: A trapezium looks like the picture below. The correct formula for the area of a trapezium is Atrapezium=h2(a+b)Atrapezium=h2(a+b). The two parallel sides of the trapezium (a and b) must be perpendicular to the height (h) of the trapezium.

  • Parallelogram: A parallelogram looks like the picture below. The correct formula for the area of a parallelogram is Aparallelogram=bhAparallelogram=bh. It is very important that the base (b) and the height (h) are perpendicular to each other. (You may notice that this is the same as the formula for the area of a rectangle.)

Perimeter and area

Study the figure below and calculate the perimeter and the area of this figure by using the given lengths in mmmm.

Answer:
  1. Perimeter = mmmm
  2. Area = mm2mm2
numeric
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

For the perimeter, you need to find the sum (the total) of the distance around the edges of the shape. For the area, you will need to use what you know about the area of rectangles.

STEP: Find the perimeter
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

The perimeter of an object is the distance around the outer boundary of a two-dimensional figure. For example, the perimeter of a soccer field is the white line around the entire field. The diagram below shows the perimeter coloured red and blue.

To find the perimeter, we need to add up all six sides of the shape. We can start at any corner we want and go around until we get back where we started. We will start at the corner labelled below.

PerimeterPerimeter=Sum of the distance around=8+8+2+4+6+4=32mmPerimeter=Sum of the distance around=8+8+2+4+6+4Perimeter=32mm
NOTE: You do not have to start at the same corner: you can start at any corner and you will get the same total distance. This is because the distance around the shape is the same no matter where you start.
STEP: Break the shape into rectangles to find the area
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

The area of a shape is the amount of surface inside the boundary of the shape. If you paint a shape, you are painting the area of the shape.

To calculate the area in this case, we need to break the shape into familar shapes like triangles or rectangles. In the case above you have two rectangles. The rectangles are labelled AA and BB. Find the area of each rectangle and then add them together to get the total area of the shape.

AreaAAreaBAreaTotal=length×width=8×4=32cm2=length×width=2×4=8cm2=AreaA+AreaB=40mm2AreaA=length×width=8×4=32cm2AreaB=length×width=2×4=8cm2AreaTotal=AreaA+AreaB=40mm2

Therefore, the perimeter is 32 mm32 mm, and the area is 40 mm240 mm2.

Submit your answer as: and

Missing lengths

Study the figure OPQRSOPQRS below. The figure is drawn to scale.

Side OP⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯=6mmOP¯=6mm , PQ⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯=PQ¯= Not given , QR⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯=8mmQR¯=8mm , RS⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯=10mmRS¯=10mm , SO⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯=6,19mmSO¯=6,19mm.

Calculate the perimeter and the area of the figure. Round your answer to two decimal places.

Answer:
  1. Perimeter = mmmm
  2. Area = mm2mm2
numeric
numeric
STEP: <no title>
[−5 points ⇒ 0 / 5 points left]

PQ⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯=OS⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯PQ¯=OS¯ (Opposite sides of a rectangle are equal)

The perimeter = 36,3836,38 mmmm

The area = 61,1461,14mm2mm2

Perimeter is the border or outer boundary of a two-dimensional figure - the "distance " you would walk around the shape. In this specific case above, you follow the red lines OP⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯OP¯ and PQ⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯PQ¯, then the blue lines QR⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯QR¯and RS⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯RS¯, then the final red line SO⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯SO¯ back to the start. Remember you are only adding distances in one dimension so the unit for your answer will be mmmm only.

PerimeterPerimeter=Sum of the distance around=6+6,19+8+10+6,19=6+6,19+8+10+6,19=36,38mmPerimeter=Sum of the distance around=6+6,19+8+10+6,19=6+6,19+8+10+6,19Perimeter=36,38mm

Area is the amount of space inside the boundary of a two-dimensional shape - the " space " inside the perimeter. To calculate the area try and divide the compound shape into simpler shapes with a familiar formula. In the case above you have areaAA a rectangle and areaBB a triangle. Remember you are multiplying mmmm by mmmm which means your unit for your answer shoud be mmmm22.

AreaAAreaBAreaTotal=length×width=6×6,19=37,14mm2=12base×height=12(6×8)=24mm2=AreaA+AreaB=61,14mm2AreaA=length×width=6×6,19=37,14mm2AreaB=12base×height=12(6×8)=24mm2AreaTotal=AreaA+AreaB=61,14mm2

Therefore, the perimeter = 36.38mm and the area = 61.14mm22.

Submit your answer as: and

Perimeter and area involving pythagoras

Study the figure XYWVU below. The figure is drawn to scale.

Side XY⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯=5cmXY¯=5cm , YW⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯=YW¯= Not given, WV⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯=4cmWV¯=4cm, VU⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯=xVU¯=x, UX⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯=11cmUX¯=11cm.

Calculate the perimeter and the area of the figure. Round your answer to one decimal place.

Answer:
  1. Perimeter = cmcm
  2. Area = cm2cm2

numeric

    2. XY⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯=WU⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯XY¯=WU¯ (Opposite sides of a rectangle are equal
    3. x is the hypotenuse side of right ΔΔ WVU. Using the Theorem of Pythagoras:
      VU⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯2VU⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯2VU⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯VU⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯=WV⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯2+UW⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯⎯2=(4)2+(5)2=41‾‾‾√=6,4cmVU¯2=WV¯2+UW¯2VU¯2=(4)2+(5)2VU¯=41VU¯=6,4cm

    PerimeterPerimeter=Sum of the distance around=5+11+4+6,4+11=5+11+4+6,4+11=37,4cmPerimeter=Sum of the distance around=5+11+4+6,4+11=5+11+4+6,4+11Perimeter=37,4cm

Perimeter and area

Study the figure below and calculate the perimeter and the area of this figure by using the given lengths in mmmm.

Answer:
  1. Perimeter = mmmm
  2. Area = mm2mm2
numeric
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

For the perimeter, you need to find the sum (the total) of the distance around the edges of the shape. For the area, you will need to use what you know about the area of rectangles.

STEP: Find the perimeter
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

The perimeter of an object is the distance around the outer boundary of a two-dimensional figure. For example, the perimeter of a soccer field is the white line around the entire field. The diagram below shows the perimeter coloured red and blue.

To find the perimeter, we need to add up all six sides of the shape. We can start at any corner we want and go around until we get back where we started. We will start at the corner labelled below.

PerimeterPerimeter=Sum of the distance around=4+5+2+3+2+2=18mmPerimeter=Sum of the distance around=4+5+2+3+2+2Perimeter=18mm
NOTE: You do not have to start at the same corner: you can start at any corner and you will get the same total distance. This is because the distance around the shape is the same no matter where you start.
STEP: Break the shape into rectangles to find the area
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

The area of a shape is the amount of surface inside the boundary of the shape. If you paint a shape, you are painting the area of the shape.

To calculate the area in this case, we need to break the shape into familar shapes like triangles or rectangles. In the case above you have two rectangles. The rectangles are labelled AA and BB. Find the area of each rectangle and then add them together to get the total area of the shape.

AreaAAreaBAreaTotal=length×width=4×2=8cm2=length×width=2×3=6cm2=AreaA+AreaB=14mm2AreaA=length×width=4×2=8cm2AreaB=length×width=2×3=6cm2AreaTotal=AreaA+AreaB=14mm2

Therefore, the perimeter is 18 mm18 mm, and the area is 14 mm214 mm2.

The perimeter of an object is the distance around the outer boundary of a two-dimensional figure. For example, the perimeter of a soccer field is the white line around the entire field. The diagram below shows the perimeter coloured red and blue.

To find the perimeter, we need to add up all six sides of the shape. We can start at any corner we want and go around until we get back where we started. We will start at the corner labelled below.

PerimeterPerimeter=Sum of the distance around=7+5+3+3+4+2=24cmPerimeter=Sum of the distance around=7+5+3+3+4+2Perimeter=24cm
NOTE: You do not have to start at the same corner: you can start at any corner and you will get the same total distance. This is because the distance around the shape is the same no matter where you start.

Circles: area and units

A circle has a radius of 8 mm8 mm. What is its area in cm2cm2?

INSTRUCTION: Use π=3,14π=3,14 in your calculation, and round your answer to two decimal places.
Answer: The area is cm2cm2.
one-of
type(numeric.abserror(0.01))
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

Start by finding the radius of the circle in cmcm. Then calculate the area in cm2cm2.

STEP: Convert the radius to cmcm
[−1 point ⇒ 2 / 3 points left]

In this question, we need to find the area of the circle in cm2cm2, but we have the radius in mmmm. One way to solve this is to start by converting the radius to cmcm, and then use this value to find the area in cm2cm2.

We know that 1 cm=10 mm1 cm=10 mm, so we need to divide the radius in mmmm by 1010. We need to divide, because 1 mm1 mm is smaller than 1 cm1 cm, so we need fewer cmcm than we have mmmm.

r=8 mm=810 cm=0,8 cmr=8 mm=810 cm=0,8 cm
STEP: Calculate the area in cm2cm2
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

Now we need to calculate the area of the circle in cm2cm2. The formula for the area of a circle is

A=πr2A=πr2

Since we know that the radius is 0,8 cm0,8 cm, we can calculate the area

A=πr2=(3,14)(0,8)2=2,0096≈2,01 cm2A=πr2=(3,14)(0,8)2=2,0096≈2,01 cm2

The correct answer for the new area of the circle is

A=2,01 cm2A=2,01 cm2

A=πr2A=πr2

Which variable is the radius in this formula?

STEP: Calculate the area of the circle
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

We need to calculate the area of the circle. The area of an object is the surface that we can cover or paint.

Let's start with the formula for the area of a circle:

A=πr2A=πr2

In this formula, the variable rr stands for the radius of the circle. The question gives us the value of rr. We need to substitute this into the formula to find the area of the circle.

A=πr2=(3,14)(2)2=(3,14)(4)=12,56 cm2A=πr2=(3,14)(2)2=(3,14)(4)=12,56 cm2

So the area is 12,56 cm212,56 cm2.

Given that the radius of the circle is 7,887,88 m, calculate the shaded area.

We are given a circle and an isosceles triangle. The triangle is drawn within the circle. The area outside the triangle is shaded. We need to calculate the area that has been shaded. [−2 points ⇒ 1 / 5 points left]

The calculation of the area of a triangle is a bit tricky. But we can use what we know about circles to find the information we need to find the triangle's area. We need to the base and the height of the triangle to calculate it's area. (Remember that the base and the height must be perpendicular.) Each vertex of the triangle is on the circumference of the circle. That means we can find the base and the height of the triangle from the radius of the circle.

We know that the radius of the circle is 7,887,88 m. The red dot is the centre of the circle, so any distance from that dot to the circle's circumference is 7,887,88 m. So we can label the diagram with the information as follows:

The height of the triangle is the same as the circle's radius. And the base of the triangle is actually one radius plus another radius. These lengths are perpendicular to each other, so we can substitute this information into the formula for the area of a triangle.

ATriangle=12bh=12(7,88+7,88)×(7,88)=12(15,76)×(7,88)=62,0944 m2ATriangle=12bh=12(7,88+7,88)×(7,88)=12(15,76)×(7,88)=62,0944 m2

[−4 points ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

We have two circles here. The following figure shows the larger cyan circle and the smaller white circle separated from each other.

To find the shaded area for this question, we need to calculate the area for both circles and then subtract. We can calculate their individual areas with the formula:

Acircle=πr2Acircle=πr2

For the cyan circle, we find the larger area:

Acyan=πr2=π(4,3)2=π(18,49)=58,08804... m2Acyan=πr2=π(4,3)2=π(18,49)=58,08804... m2

For the white circle, we find the smaller area:

Awhite=πr2=π(3,25)2=π(10,5625)=33,18307... m2Awhite=πr2=π(3,25)2=π(10,5625)=33,18307... m2

Then to find the area of the cyan region in the original picture, we need to subtract the area of the white circle from the area of the cyan circle:

Acyan only=Acyan−Awhite=(58,08804...)−(33,18307...)=24,90497...=24,9 m2Acyan only=Acyan−Awhite=(58,08804...)−(33,18307...)=24,90497...=24,9 m2
NOTE: Remember to round your answer to two decimal places.

Therefore, the area of the cyan region is 24,9 m224,9 m2.

Area of a circle

A circle has a radius of 2 m2 m.

What is the area of the circle?

INSTRUCTION: Use π=3,14π=3,14 in your calculation.
Answer: The area is m2m2.
one-of
type(numeric.abserror(0.004))
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

The formula for the area of a circle is

A=πr2A=πr2

Which variable is the radius in this formula?

STEP: Calculate the area of the circle
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

We need to calculate the area of the circle. The area of an object is the surface that we can cover or paint.

Let's start with the formula for the area of a circle:

A=πr2A=πr2

In this formula, the variable rr stands for the radius of the circle. The question gives us the value of rr. We need to substitute this into the formula to find the area of the circle.

A=πr2=(3,14)(2)2=(3,14)(4)=12,56 m2A=πr2=(3,14)(2)2=(3,14)(4)=12,56 m2

So the area is 12,56 m212,56 m2.

Areas involving shapes

The following diagram shows a circle and an isosceles triangle drawn within the circle. The vertices of the triangle lie on the circumference of the circle. There is a dot at the center of the circle. The area outside the triangle is shaded.

Given that the radius of the circle is 6,036,03 mm, calculate the shaded area.

INSTRUCTION: Round your answer to 22 decimal places.
Answer:

The shaded area ≈≈ mm2mm2.

one-of
type(numeric.noerror)
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 5 / 5 points left]

Calculate the areas of the circle and the triangle separately and then substract the area of the triangle from the circle of the circle. Use the fact that the triangle is isosceles to find its height.

STEP: Determine the strategy
[−1 point ⇒ 4 / 5 points left]

We are given a circle and an isosceles triangle. The triangle is drawn within the circle. The area outside the triangle is shaded. We need to calculate the area that has been shaded. To do that, we will calculate the areas of the two shapes separately and then subtract the area of the triangle from the area of the circle.

STEP: Calculate the area of the circle
[−1 point ⇒ 3 / 5 points left]

The area of the circle (AcircleAcircle) is:

Acircle=πr2=π(6,03)2=π(36,3609)=114,23113... mm2Acircle=πr2=π(6,03)2=π(36,3609)=114,23113... mm2
STEP: Calculate the area of the triangle
[−2 points ⇒ 1 / 5 points left]

The calculation of the area of a triangle is a bit tricky. But we can use what we know about circles to find the information we need to find the triangle's area. We need to the base and the height of the triangle to calculate it's area. (Remember that the base and the height must be perpendicular.) Each vertex of the triangle is on the circumference of the circle. That means we can find the base and the height of the triangle from the radius of the circle.

We know that the radius of the circle is 6,036,03 mm. The red dot is the centre of the circle, so any distance from that dot to the circle's circumference is 6,036,03 mm. So we can label the diagram with the information as follows:

The height of the triangle is the same as the circle's radius. And the base of the triangle is actually one radius plus another radius. These lengths are perpendicular to each other, so we can substitute this information into the formula for the area of a triangle.

ATriangle=12bh=12(6,03+6,03)×(6,03)=12(12,06)×(6,03)=36,3609 mm2ATriangle=12bh=12(6,03+6,03)×(6,03)=12(12,06)×(6,03)=36,3609 mm2
STEP: Calculate the shaded area
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 5 points left]

To find the shaded area, we need subtract the area of the triangle from that of the circle:

AshadedRound to twodecimal places→=Acircle−ATriangle=(114,23113...)−(36,3609)=77,87023...≈77,87mm2Ashaded=Acircle−ATriangle=(114,23113...)−(36,3609)=77,87023...decimal placesRound to two→≈77,87mm2

The shaded area ≈77,87mm2≈77,87mm2.

Submit your answer as:
